I loved Descent as an adolescent, and Overload ticks all the right boxes. If you were a fan of Descent, you'll feel right at home.

If you never played Descent, be aware of some of its challenges. It's very easy to get lost on the maps, especially as you're trying to make your escape. Some areas have cues to help, but they're a bit inconsistent on that front. Harder difficulty levels mean a LOT of dodging, and the lack of an NPC paradigm of consequence means that if you're not playing multiplayer, you're going to feel a bit lonely.

All in all, an excellent game that's well worth its cost, and props for the developers for keeping the core tenets of such a great game in what is more than simply a reskin or a nostalgia grab, but a great game in its own right.

Overload is a game which is, simply, Descent. If you're familiar with that series of games you need to know absolutely nothing else, and so if you enjoyed those games, no doubt you'll find the same fun with these, only with updated sounds and graphics (to be quite honest sometimes I kind of expect the sounds to still be all chunky and retro-styled while playing).  If you hated those games, you have something wrong in your life and no, you will not enjoy this game. However, for those seeking enlightenment on the topic, let me tell you what Descent/Overload is. It's a series of games which focus on the idea of the player being a spaceship in a 6 degrees of freedom environment (this is code for "there is no up or down" and your ship will turn exactly as you move the mouse) named "material defender" (This is only stated in Descent and because the ships looks the same I assume that's the name here too) which has been sent to liberate a string of mining operations from some sort of rogue AI takeover being headed by a big reactor which presumably houses the head of the mess. Actually, scrach that, it's canonically some sort of robo-virus. I forget the exact plot of the Descent series because it was never that strong. In order to fulfill your mission you are provided a few weapons along the way which range from laser to missiles to a psuedo-shotgun to a glorified miniature nuke to etc. Each level follows a standard format: You spawn in, progress along a fairly linear course while taking on robots that make their best attempt to stop you, finally reach the reactor which you must destroy, and escape the base afterwards. There is also an upgrade system, but enough about all of that, let me toss everything into Pro-Con format:
Pros:
 + Weapons are satisfying to use and are all reminiscent of the Descent 2 arsenal (impulse lasers are the standard laser, hunter missiles are the homing missiles, the driller is the guass cannon, etc.). No one weapon is really left out to dry in terms of practicality.
 + Music is an obvious homage to the style of music used for the original Descent games. A good job here.
 + Enemy variety is pretty wild, so don't expect to be bored by one and the same robot each time. 
 + Level design is really good except for one level.
 + Controls are pretty smooth and even the "spaceship sway" from the original games is emulated (what spaceship sway means is that turning your ship usually doesn't stop it on the spot, rather it kinds of tapers down in speed).
 + Obviously made with care, seeing as the development team from the other Descent games is working on it after seeing how bad Descent: Underground was butchered (Hint: It was butchered so bad you can't even buy it on Steam anymore).
 + A nifty upgrade system which, while not the most useful thing, is a pretty good addition to the game and does no harm.
Cons: 
 - I don't know how bad a startup screen can get but this is the worst I've seen. Each time you boot up the game it starts with a black screen until you task manager out and get back into the window again, and even after that it still sometimes stops and freezes or even worse, crashes. 
 - The level "Titan Observatory" feels like something out of Serious Sam, and while I'm all for those games, this is not the place for a Serious Sam level. Titan Observatory just floods you with tons of brainless enemies, all of which you need to deal with in an usually open area without much in the way of "creative cover". Also, it introduced a BS new enemy type which is slow and does nothing but hurl an endless stream of rockets at you non-stop. Also, any level is too long if you hear the music track loop more than 10 times in one playthrough. This is a level that needs a serious rework. 
 - The BS enemy previously described.

Total: 9 / 10
This is what a faithful continuation of a series looks like. I'm looking at you, Descent Underground development team (multiplayer bullshit comes first my ass).

A smooth, streamlined 6DoF shooter with a history long predating its development.

From the people who made Descent so many years ago, a modernization of the same mechanics (without the same title, for legal reasons). Even the weapons are mostly the same concept. That's not to say that the game isn't original or inventive; there are plenty of things unique to it as well (time bombs, creepers, the overload powerup). The game simply draws from an older inspiration, and is therefore better thought-out, and has even picked up some of the old community surrounding Descent.

The ship is a joy to control, and all the weapons and so on are intuitive and responsive. The game has an easy setting on which you can demolish hundreds of enemies, but it can also get very challenging if you set it that way. The atmosphere can vary from map to map, but it tends to be a little dark and somber. Not a horror game, but dark nonetheless. A lot like its predecessor, Descent.

As it currently stands, the game has three story-mode (read: campaign, there is no real story) levels, and an infinite survival sort of "challenge mode" with eight or nine maps. The challenge mode can get a little repetitive in my opinion, but it takes a while. Updates have been regular and never fail to introduce something new and interesting. The game also has the ability to give you a good deal of statistical information on your own performance (if that interests you).

I'm not, and never was, a "Triple-D" (Devout-Descent-Disciple) - I admired the concept, but simply didn't fall in love with 6DOF back in the 90's. 

There are enough reviews from "Triple-D's" here on Steam as well as the Overload forums, that virtually everything positive about Overload has already been said - so what can I add as an apparent "pagan"?

For those gamers that perhaps have either never indulged in a 6DOF affair, or have dipped their toes in, but found the temprature somewhat uncomfortable, Overload is a breath of fresh air - because it works flawlessly and is absolutely accessible in a very minimalistic way ! When it comes to gaming that involves wreaking explosive havoc on any form of enemy by means of an impressive incendiary arsenal, there are some critical factors that must be in place to hook me and keep me coming back for more: minimal time spent in config/setup menus, pitch-perfect and responsive controls, ambience and immersion (art-style, sound, lighting), simple and compelling gameplay. I was having fun with Overload within 10 minutes in much the same way that ID games captivated me back in the 90's - all of the ingredients were there!

Challenge mode alone is currently worth the price of admission, although the MP component (available in 2018?) will hopefully provide a few game modes similar to UT3 (i.e. bot matches) thereby providing eons of fun for years to come. 

Again, for anyone relatively new to this genre, but with a love of FPS's, this won't disappoint, especially given the support  for various control devices ! You certainly don't need to be a "Triple-D" or a flight-sim genius to enjoy this high octane, easily accessible, addictive arcade shooter and at this point, it's hard to pinpoint any significant negative aspects of the game.

Very much so feels like the old greats and then some. Design, direction, artwork, effects, music, and of course the weapons. It's like they took every sick af part of the best mid-90s scifi games with unconventional designs and jammed them all into a complete package but re-tooling them to be very effective and even somewhat believable.

The music? A fantastic and fitting blend of techno, electrorchestra, some tech house/trance(???) flavors, and of course that industrial techno jam. The track for the Syrinx challenge level even uses the signature, calling-card compressed drums, the legendary pads, and even some other techno samples, from all kinds of popular industrial music. Not like DooM'16 industrial, but that oldschool techno-industrial stuff.

The lighting engine is used very well, with properly decorated levels, PBR that doesn't look like that generic metallic garbage (polished stone tile looks like polished stone tile), and it appears to be fairly optimized, even with a ton of flares lying around (bright innit?). The weapon effects also leave little to nothing wanting. Each weapon looks like it was hand-crafted before even being made public, now some of the more advanced additional effects for upgrades might not appear until later, but even some of the basic ones appear, like for upgrades to the Impulse and Flak. The weapon model, the muzzle flash, the projectile, the heat trail of the Driller and the Flak's heat wave from saturating the area in front of you with pyrotechnics, and the impact effects. Either particles or a mesh, but they're definitely not sprites. Robot weapons included.

Robot parts looking damaged and then flying off (purely decorative) is made clear to add to the visceral nature of action games of this sort, and their death rolls complete with flame, smoke, and eventual collapse are no exception. Their loot not being exposed until they actually explode, leaving fiery particle trails and shrapnel everywhere (you can speed this up by shooting their failing chassis).

On top of that there are tons of little details on the HUD even though it's minimalist. It's still quite utilitarian and provides important info at a glance, and a really useful reticle that includes a minimal display of ammo and shields, with unique patterns for each primary (none for the secondaries yet, besides the heavies which have a orange outline). The Cyclone spreadgun even has a secondary reticle that shows you it's next firing arcs.

Robot AI is intelligent and savage. Each machine having it's own behavior and temperment, increasing in agression as you piss them off with a baseline of whatever difficulty you pick. They'll even push you into a corner room if they can. I've put a lot of hours into Descent 2 who's AI design still holds up to this day, and I can tell you with certainty that the AI in this game is even more nasty.

As for you, you get a lot of choices, even in the first release there are more matterguns and a wider variety of weapon designs than one would normally expect, and there are improved versions of some the old greats. Plenty of different secondaries to toy with as well. The dumbfires are fast and brutal; homings are slow but agile. You've even got pod rockets. Homing pod rockets. The upgades give you even more choices and make some weapons take a step back to take two steps forward, like the Driller firing smaller projectiles but faster for more DPS and less punishing misses, or how you can slap a small guidance system onto the Falcon dumbfires.

Oh, and you can shoot through grates. Just thought I should mention that.

Overall this game is shaping up very quickly, with a constant flow of bugfixes and optimizations, and steady work on the major elements. It's only been in-dev for three years and they've already got a lot of the important stuff done or at least in a position to be completed without any nasty roadblocks, and they're not even close to done. Their dedication is very clear and present, making it absolutely worth the asking price of 25$.


Finally I want to make something clear. This game is not "oh hey check out all these 6dof games coming out, wanna revisit the good old days?" They planed this as early as 2014, before they had even heard of D:U (i'm only 75% certain of this particular fact), and before SL0 was anything more than a Ludum Dare. They literally got to talking about a new game and were like "wanna make another 6DOF game?" ... "HELL YEAH" and so they got most of the Old Guard back together and some new chaps as well. This is the game they've waited nearly two decades to make.

Wyverns are elusive critters, while bladed 'Shredders' charge at you with alarming regularity. In case anybody thinks it's relevant, I backed this game on Kickstarter. In any event, Overload is shaping up to be a fantastic spiritual successor to the Descent series. I play with mouse and keyboard, and the flight feels exactly right once I turn off mouse smoothing, turn mouse limiting to strong, and enable full trichording by pushing F8 in-game.

Right now there's a training mission, a campaign-style mission (blow up the reactor and get out!), two challenge modes across four extremely well-designed maps, and several highly-varied weapons and bots. They've also introduced a new physical smash attack, and there's no more badass feeling than smashing a superbot to scrap metal. There are five difficulty levels, with separate leaderboards for each, and the most difficult must be unlocked for each map; this challenge is sure to keep you coming back if you're the competitive type.

It's worth highlighting the variety of even just the four maps and weapons -- one map is bright with relatively open spaces, another is arranged in a geometric pattern of tunnels and medium-sized rooms, and the other two are full of dark, foreboding tunnels. Because of the different spaces and lighting, each map encourages the use of different weapons and tactics -- the Reflex Cannon probably won't be your first choice on open Syrinx, but it bounces around in deadly fashion in the narrow tunnels of Labyrinth and Caverns.

The development team is also using dynamic lighting throughout each map. This choice gives the darker maps an exquisitely creepy atmosphere, as you can see the bots' headlights growing more intense on the wall around a corner as they draw near.

The bots themselves are diverse and interactive. They have a variety of behaviors, from swarming and chasing to running to (as far as I can tell!) predicting your escape and trying to cut you off. In short: 

This game is literally Descent. You may make your own mind up as to whether or not that's a recommendation.

To go into more detail:

Were you born in the late 80s or early 90s? Did play flight-sim/shoot-'em-up hybrids like Hellbender and Descent religiously? Do you enjoy the thought of guiltlessly murdering a variety of hovering robots with a colourful selection of guns and missiles? Do you like flying around in extremely constrained spaces?

Congratulations - you will love this game!

When I write reviews on Steam, I try to shy away from the whole "if you liked X, then you'll love this game" cliché, but in this case I think it's appropriate. If you liked Descent or any of its direct sequels, you will very likely love this game, because it's literally just Descent but with better graphics. All the guns and missiles are more or less straight ports of weapons from the old games with new names. The robots are different to some degree, but even there I could see some obvious design similarities. Everything is more or less the same.

This also includes the claustrophobic, labyrinthine level design, the dozens of genuinely secret secret areas in each level, the fast-paced, nerve-racking gameplay and a pretty period-accurate soundtrack. The controls need a little bit of work here and there, but they're generally as tight and responsive as I remember then being back when I was 9 and only very slightly worse at video games than I am at 29.

Beyond a fairly simple upgrade system, this game makes no real attempt to innovate on the Descent formula. The slight changes it makes to core systems from the old games feel like additions that should always have been there. And for fans of Descent 3, I should say that aside from the general look and feel of the game, this game cribs far more heavily from Descent 1 and Descent 2 than the third installment. You shouldn't expect any wide-open outdoor spaces, mission control updates or gigantic set-piece boss fights in this game.

I had genuine fun playing the four missions currently available for this game, and it's one of the few Early Access titles I felt was genuinely worth my money. I can't say for sure whether you'll feel the same. This game is decidedly a nostalgia trip, and if you were never a fan of Descent or you want something that takes the genre some place new, this game will not satisfy you.

But I loved it.
